Xi Jinping:
Xi Jinping was born on June 15, 1953 in Beijing, China.  He comes from a politically influential family, as his father Xi Zhongxun was a leading communist politician. 

During his youth, Xi Jinping experienced the Cultural Revolution in China, which lasted from 1966 to 1976.  This time strongly influenced him, and he recognized the importance of stable and corruption-free government. 

Xi Jinping enrolled at Tsinghua University, where he completed his studies in engineering.  He then began his political career in various provinces of China. 

His political experience includes leading the provinces of Fujian and Zhejiang, where he gained a reputation as a dynamic and efficient politician.  During his tenure as Party Secretary in Zhejiang, Xi Jinping initiated a variety of reforms that propelled the economic growth and development of the province. 

In 2007, Xi Jinping was elected to the Politburo of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and quickly rose through the ranks of the party hierarchy.  In 2012, he was appointed General Secretary of the Communist Party of China and Chairman of the Central Military Commission, thereby holding the two highest positions in the country. 

As the head of state and party, Xi Jinping has pursued a "comprehensive reform agenda" and advocated for a stronger role for China in global politics.  He has taken measures to combat corruption within the party, reduce environmental pollution, and modernize the Chinese economy. 

Since then, Xi Jinping has become one of the most influential political figures in the world.  He has firmly established his role as China's leader and is often compared to former Chairman Mao Zedong. 

Nevertheless, he is accused by some critics of restricting freedom of expression and neglecting human rights.  His aggressive foreign policy and treatment of minorities such as the Uighurs in Xinjiang have also attracted global attention. 

Xi Jinping is married to Peng Liyuan, a well-known singer and member of the People's Liberation Army.  The couple has a daughter named Xi Mingze. 

Overall, it can be said that Xi Jinping is a central figure in China's political landscape and his policies will continue to significantly influence the country and the world in the years to come.
Narendra Modi:
Narendra Modi, full name Narendra Damodardas Modi, was born on September 17, 1950 in Vadnagar, a small village in the Indian state of Gujarat.  He is an Indian politician and has been the 14th Prime Minister of India since 2014. 

In his youth, Modi worked in his family's tea stall, where he first encountered social inequalities and poverty in India.  The desire to address these issues and bring about change motivated him to get involved in politics.  At the age of only eighteen, Modi joined the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a nationalist organization known for promoting Hindu culture and values. 

Modi began his political career as a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and quickly rose within the party.  He was appointed as the Chief Minister of Gujarat in 2001 and held this position for a total of thirteen years.  During his tenure as Chief Minister, Modi focused on the economic development of Gujarat and advocated for improving the infrastructure and education system.  However, his policies were not without controversy, especially due to the unrest in Gujarat in 2002, where hundreds of people, mainly Muslims, lost their lives.  Modi was accused of not doing enough to contain the violence, although he denied any responsibility. 

In 2014, Modi led the BJP to victory in the parliamentary elections and was appointed as Prime Minister.  Under his leadership, India has implemented numerous economic reforms to promote growth and reduce bureaucracy.  Modi has also launched initiatives to promote renewable energy and end open defecation to improve sanitary conditions in rural areas. 

As a charismatic leader, Modi has both supporters and critics in Indian politics.  His supporters appreciate his determination and ambition to transform India, while his opponents express concerns about his nationalist agenda and his handling of minorities. 

Modi has received a number of international awards, including the highest civilian award in Abu Dhabi and the highest civilian award in the southwest of Saudi Arabia.  His popularity in India has remained strong, and he was re-elected for a second term as Prime Minister in 2019. 

Narendra Modi remains a key figure in Indian politics and continues to strive to modernize India and drive its growth.  His biography reflects a remarkable rise from a tea stall worker to Prime Minister and remains a fascinating example of political success and commitment to social change.
Joko Widodo:
Joko Widodo, also known as Jokowi, was born on June 21, 1961 in the Indonesian city of Surakarta.  Although he grew up in a modest family, Jokowi had a dream early on to bring about change in his country. 

After completing his studies at Gadjah Mada University in Yogyakarta, Jokowi started his professional career as a furniture trader.  His ability to make a name for himself in the business world quickly earned him the respect and recognition of his fellow citizens. 

In 2005, Jokowi joined the Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle and began his political career.  He was elected as the Mayor of Surakarta and worked intensively to modernize the city and improve the quality of life for its people.  Under his leadership, Surakarta experienced remarkable economic development and was considered one of the most livable cities in Indonesia. 

In 2012, Jokowi ran for elections again and was elected as the Governor of Jakarta.  As Governor, he advocated for social justice, education, and infrastructure projects.  His focus was on developing the poorer neighborhoods that had often been neglected.  Jokowi was known for his down-to-earth nature and his ability to appeal to people from various social backgrounds. 

Due to his successes as Governor and his popular policies, Jokowi was nominated as the presidential candidate for the 2014 elections.  He won the election against his competitors and became Indonesia's seventh president.  Jokowi took office with the promise to reduce economic inequality, combat corruption, and improve the country's infrastructure. 

During his presidency, Jokowi has initiated numerous reforms to propel Indonesia forward.  He has advocated for promoting economic growth, creating jobs, and improving education and healthcare.  Jokowi has also taken measures to address climate change and protect the environment. 

Despite some challenges and controversies, Jokowi has received broad approval and support during his term.  His reputation as a "people's president" has made him one of the most popular politicians in Indonesia. 

Joko Widodo is a man of the people who started his political career to improve the lives of people in Indonesia.  Through his dedication and vision, he has earned a place in history as one of the most influential politicians in the country.  His biography is an example of the power of will and the influence that a person can have when they truly want to bring about change.
Mamnoon Hussain:
Mamnoon Hussain was born on December 23, 1940 in Agra, India.  He came from a wealthy family and completed his early education in his hometown.  In 1949, his family moved to Karachi, Pakistan, where he continued his secondary education. 

After completing his schooling, Mamnoon Hussain decided to enter the textile sector.  He founded a successful textile company called "Mamnoon Hussain Textiles," which made him a respected entrepreneur. 

During his professional career, Hussain also became involved in the political arena.  He became an active member of the Muslim League and supported the party in various campaigns.  Due to his commitment and leadership qualities, Hussain quickly gained recognition and was elected as the Chairman of the Karachi Chapter of the Muslim League. 

In 1997, Mamnoon Hussain was elected as the President of the Karachi Chamber of Commerce and Industry.  In this role, he worked hard to promote trade and the economy in Karachi and played a significant role in strengthening economic relations between Pakistan and other countries. 

In 2013, Mamnoon Hussain was elected as the 12th President of Pakistan as a candidate of the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N).  He assumed office on September 9, 2013 and held the position until September 9, 2018. 

During his presidency, Hussain focused on promoting education and economic development in Pakistan.  He supported various initiatives to increase literacy and educational opportunities in the country.  Additionally, he advocated for a business-friendly policy to attract foreign investments and boost economic growth. 

After the end of his term as President, Mamnoon Hussain retired from active politics.  Instead, he dedicated his time to his family and personal interests. 

Mamnoon Hussain is considered a respected entrepreneur and politician in Pakistan.  His contributions to the promotion of economy and education in the country have earned him recognition and respect.  Despite his withdrawal from politics, he continues to be an inspiring figure for many people in Pakistan.
Sheikh Hasina:
Sheikh Hasina, the current Prime Minister of Bangladesh, was born on September 28, 1947 in Tungipara, then East Pakistan.  She is the eldest daughter of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, the founder and first Prime Minister of the country, and Begum Fazilatunnesa Mujib. 

Hasina was born into a politically active family and witnessed her father's efforts to create an independent Bangladesh from a young age.  Her father played a crucial role in leading the country's independence movement against Pakistan in the 1970s. 

Her political career began at a young age.  She joined the political party Awami League, founded by her father, and quickly became a key party leader.  After the assassination of her father and many other family members by the military regime in 1975, she went into exile in India. 

During her exile, Sheikh Hasina continued her political work and aimed to restore democracy in Bangladesh.  In 1981, she founded the Gano Forum party and became a respected voice in the political resistance against the then authoritarian regime. 

Upon her return to Bangladesh in 1981, she was repeatedly imprisoned and faced political suppression.  Nonetheless, she remained determined and steadfast in her fight for democracy and human rights. 

Hasina eventually achieved a major success when her party Awami League won a landslide victory in the 1996 parliamentary elections.  She was elected as the country's first female Prime Minister and took office on June 23, 1996. 

As Prime Minister, Sheikh Hasina implemented numerous reforms to modernize Bangladesh and improve the lives of its people.  Her government introduced measures to combat poverty, promote education, strengthen economic development, and protect human rights. 

Hasina led Bangladesh through challenging times, including the impacts of climate change, natural disasters, and refugee crises.  Her leadership and determination helped the country to face challenges and bring about positive change. 

For her tireless efforts to strengthen democracy and the well-being of people, Sheikh Hasina has been globally recognized.  She has received numerous international awards, including the Indira Gandhi Peace Prize and the Champions of the Earth Award. 

Sheikh Hasina remains a prominent figure in politics and continues her work to make Bangladesh a prosperous and developed country.  Her vision, leadership, and determination have shaped the country and earned her the respect and admiration of many people.
Shinzo Abe:
Shinzo Abe was born on September 21, 1954 in Tokyo, Japan.  He is a political leader and has served as the Prime Minister of Japan twice.  Abe comes from a politically influential family; his maternal grandfather was Nobusuke Kishi, the Prime Minister of Japan in the 1950s. 

Abe completed his education at Seikei High School in Tokyo and then pursued a degree in political science at the University of Tokyo.  He graduated in 1977 and started his career in his father's office, Shintaro Abe, who was the Foreign Minister at the time. 

In 1982, Abe joined the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and was first elected to the Japanese House of Representatives in 1993.  Over the years, he held various positions within the party, including that of Secretary General. 

In 2006, Abe was elected as the Prime Minister of Japan.  During his term, he advocated for an economic reform agenda known as "Abenomics. " This included measures to boost the economy, such as easing monetary policy and promoting investments. 

However, Abe faced health issues in 2007, leading to his resignation.  He returned as Prime Minister in 2012 and continued to advance his policies.  During his second term, Abe implemented controversial defense legislation reforms, allowing Japan to deploy its forces abroad. 

Abe resigned again as Prime Minister in September 2020 due to health reasons.  During his nearly eight-year tenure, he became one of the most influential figures in Japanese politics and implemented numerous political and economic reforms. 

Shinzo Abe is appreciated for his vision of an active and confident role for Japan in international politics.  Throughout his term, he strengthened relations with other countries, particularly with the United States.  He is also praised for his determination and resilience in challenging times. 

As a political figure, Shinzo Abe has had a significant impact on modern Japanese history.  His legacy in the country will be felt for many years, and he will be remembered as one of the most influential Prime Ministers of Japan.
Benigno Aquino III:
Benigno Simeon Cojuangco Aquino III, commonly known as Noynoy Aquino, was born on February 8, 1960 in Manila, Philippines, as the only son of former Philippine President Corazon Aquino and opposition leader and army hero Benigno S.  Aquino Jr. 

Aquino's life was marked by political activism and familial tragedy.  In 1983, his father, a prominent critic of Ferdinand Marcos' authoritarian regime, was assassinated upon his return from exile at Manila airport.  This event changed the lives of the Aquino family and the entire country.  Aquino followed in his father's footsteps and entered the political arena to fight for the democratic rights of the Philippines. 

After his mother's death in 2009, Aquino decided to enter politics as well and successfully ran for the presidency of the Philippines.  He led a campaign focusing on themes such as combating corruption, economic development, and social justice. 

In 2010, Aquino was elected as the 15th President of the Philippines.  During his tenure, he implemented a series of reforms to combat corruption and restore investors' confidence in the country.  He also influenced economic development by promoting education, infrastructure projects, and expanding the tourism sector. 

Although his term was marked by many challenges such as natural disasters and political unrest, Aquino was generally regarded as a successful president for his efforts towards transparency and integrity.  International observers considered the Philippines under his leadership as an emerging economy. 

Aquino's presidency ended in 2016.  Despite not seeking further political career, he remained a dedicated political observer and a strong critic of the subsequent government. 

On June 24, 2021, Benigno Aquino III passed away at the age of 61 due to heart and kidney failure.  His death triggered national mourning in the Philippines and was mourned by political leaders worldwide. 

Aquino's legacy will be remembered as an impressive combination of political heritage and personal commitment to improving the living conditions of the Philippines.  His determination to promote democratic principles and create a truly transparent and progressive country has had a profound impact on Philippine politics and society.
Tr\u01b0\u01a1ng T\u1ea5n Sang:
Trương Tấn Sang was born on January 21, 1949 in Long An Province, Vietnam.  He grew up in a modest family and early on felt the need to advocate for the rights and well-being of people. 

In the 1960s, Trương Tấn Sang joined the national liberation movement and participated in the fight against French colonial rule.  For this reason, he had to interrupt his education and join the armed resistance.  Despite his young age and his family's concerns, he showed exceptional determination and commitment to the cause. 

After Vietnam gained independence from France, Trương Tấn Sang dedicated himself to the task of rebuilding and social development of the country.  He earned a degree in economics and worked in various roles in the government and the Communist Party. 

In 2011, Trương Tấn Sang reached the peak of his political career when he was elected President of Vietnam.  As President, he played a crucial role in promoting economic growth, modernizing infrastructure, and strengthening Vietnam's position in the international community.  He also advocated for social justice and the protection of human rights by implementing programs to combat poverty and promote education and healthcare. 

Trương Tấn Sang was known for his ability to build bridges and establish diplomatic relations with other countries.  During his tenure, he worked closely with the United Nations, the European Union, and the USA to promote trade and economic cooperation. 

In 2016, after his presidential term ended, Trương Tấn Sang stepped down and retired from active politics.  He dedicated his time to passing on his experiences and mentoring young leaders.  His contributions to Vietnam's development and his commitment to social justice and human rights have earned him great respect and recognition both within and outside the country. 

Trương Tấn Sang is regarded as one of the most prominent and respected political leaders in Vietnam.  His dedication to the interests of the people and his commitment to a better future have shaped his life and career, and his legacy will be forever anchored in Vietnam's history.
Recep Tayyip Erdo\u011fan:
Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, born on February 26, 1954 in Istanbul, Turkey, is a Turkish politician and the current President of Turkey.  He is considered one of the most influential figures in Turkish politics in recent decades. 

Erdoğan was born in an Armenian neighborhood in the Kasımpaşa district of Istanbul.  His father was a seafaring captain, and his mother was a housewife.  He grew up in impoverished conditions and had to work hard from an early age to contribute to his family's livelihood. 

As a young man, Erdoğan joined the youth organization of the Islamic-conservative National View Party (Milli Görüş).  During his studies at Marmara University in Istanbul, he became familiar with political ideologies and Islamic ways of thinking that would shape his later political life. 

His political career began in the 1990s when he was elected Mayor of Istanbul.  During his term as mayor from 1994 to 1998, he implemented a series of infrastructure projects that made him a popular and respected political leader in Turkey.  However, his policies were also seen as authoritarian and Islamist by critics. 

In 2001, Erdoğan founded the Justice and Development Party (AKP) and became its leader.  The AKP quickly became one of the most influential political parties in the country and won the parliamentary elections in 2002.  Erdoğan became the Prime Minister of Turkey and led the country through a period of economic stability and reforms. 

Under Erdoğan's leadership, Turkey became a key player in regional and global politics.  He advocated for Turkey's accession to the European Union and implemented important political and economic reforms.  However, his political decisions were highly controversial within Turkey.  Critics accused him of ruling in an authoritarian manner and restricting freedom of speech. 

In 2014, Erdoğan was elected President of Turkey.  During his presidency, he pushed for an enhancement of presidential powers and held a controversial constitutional referendum in 2017 to establish a presidential system.  Since then, he has pursued a divisive political agenda that has been criticized by some as authoritarian and undemocratic. 

Erdoğan remains a polarizing political leader, both within Turkey and internationally.  While some praise him for his efforts in economic development and strengthening Turkey, others accuse him of disregarding human rights and undermining democracy.  His political future and his impact on Turkey and the international community remain uncertain.
Hassan Rouhani:
Hassan Rouhani was born on November 12, 1948, in the city of Sorkheh in Iran.  He grew up in an agriculturally oriented family and was the fifth of seven children. 

Rouhani received his early education in his hometown and then moved to Tehran to study at the College of Islamic Studies.  There, he earned a bachelor's degree in theology and went on to further his education in the United Kingdom.  He enrolled at Glasgow Caledonian University and successfully completed his studies in law. 

Upon his return to Iran in 1979, Rouhani joined the Islamic Revolution and supported the religious leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.  He joined the Islamic Republic of Iran News Agency and later became the parliamentary press secretary. 

Throughout his political career, Rouhani held a variety of positions in Iran.  From 1989 to 2005, he was a member of parliament, where he chaired various committees and played a key role in the passage of national laws.  During this time, he was also appointed as the head of the National Security Council. 

Known for his moderate views and diplomatic skills, Rouhani was elected as the President of Iran in 2013.  He took office with a promise to improve the country's international image and strengthen international relations.  During his tenure, he sought closer ties with the West and played a crucial role in the negotiations on the Iran nuclear deal, known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA). 

Rouhani's political course was criticized by some in Iran, especially by conservative hardliners who considered him too lenient towards the West.  Nevertheless, he was able to successfully complete his term and was re-elected for a second term in 2017. 

Hassan Rouhani is appreciated for his ability to find political compromises and seek diplomatic solutions.  He has advocated for a moderate policy in Iran, aiming to modernize the country economically and introduce political reforms. 

Rouhani's term ended in 2021, and it remains to be seen how his political career will continue.  He has undoubtedly made a lasting impression in Iran and internationally as a politician advocating for moderate policies and better relations with other countries.
Prayut Chan-o-cha:
Prayut Chan-o-cha was born on March 21, 1954 in the province of Nakhon Ratchasima in Thailand.  He is a Thai army officer and politician who has been the Prime Minister of Thailand since 2014. 

Chan-o-cha completed his schooling in 1971 and then joined the Royal Thai Army Academy.  After graduating from the military school, he joined the 21st Infantry Division of the Thai Army, where he held various positions and earned a reputation as an effective commander. 

During his military career, Chan-o-cha also completed several advanced military training programs.  He completed the Fort Benning Tactical Officer Basic Course in the United States, the Royal College of Defence Studies in the UK, and the National Defence College of Thailand. 

In 2010, Chan-o-cha was promoted to General of the Royal Thai Army and assumed the position of Army Commander-in-Chief.  During his tenure, he was actively involved in suppressing the political uprising of the Red Shirts that took place in Thailand from 2010 to 2011. 

In 2014, Chan-o-cha led a military coup against the ruling government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, which was accompanied by many protests and political unrest.  As the Army Commander-in-Chief, he seized power and acted as the chairman of the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO), a military government that ruled the country until the elections in 2019. 

During his time as Prime Minister, Chan-o-cha implemented various political reforms and tried to promote political stability and economic development in the country.  However, his policies have been viewed as undemocratic and authoritarian by some critics. 

Prayut Chan-o-cha was confirmed as Prime Minister in the 2019 elections, thus retaining his position.  His government faces challenges such as handling the COVID-19 pandemic, strengthening the economy, and promoting national unity. 

Chan-o-cha is married and has two children.  Despite his military and political career, he is considered one of the most influential politicians in Thailand by many in the country.  His biography remains closely intertwined with the history and politics of Thailand to this day.
Thein Sein:
The biography of Thein Sein is characterized by many years of political career and the responsibility as President of Myanmar from 2011 to 2016. 

Thein Sein was born on April 20, 1945 in Kyonku, a small town in the Irrawaddy region.  Poverty shaped his childhood, but he was determined to create a better future for himself and his family through education and hard work. 

At the age of 20, Thein Sein joined the army where he received his military training.  He quickly rose through the ranks and served in various military positions.  His achievements were recognized, and he was promoted to Brigadier General in 1997. 

In 2003, he was appointed as the Prime Minister of Myanmar, a position he held until 2011.  During his tenure, he played a crucial role in implementing economic and political reforms by advocating for the country's opening up, the release of political prisoners, and the improvement of human rights situation.  Due to these efforts, Thein Sein gained international recognition. 

In November 2010, Myanmar held its first elections in 20 years, and Thein Sein's party, the Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP), won the most seats in parliament.  On March 30, 2011, Thein Sein was sworn in as the first civilian President in almost five decades. 

During his presidency, Thein Sein continued his reform agenda.  He initiated negotiations with opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi to advance political reforms and lead the country towards a democratic path.  Under his leadership, economic reforms were also introduced to drive the growth and development of the country. 

Despite some successes, Thein Sein was also criticized for human rights violations and the ongoing suppression of ethnic minorities in Myanmar.  In particular, the conflict with the Rohingya minority led to international criticism and accusations of human rights abuses. 

In 2016, Thein Sein stepped down after the end of his presidential term and largely withdrew from the political arena.  However, he continued to dedicate himself to humanitarian projects and advocate for the promotion of education and economic development. 

The biography of Thein Sein reflects a man who rose from humble beginnings to become the most powerful man in Myanmar.  His efforts towards political and economic reforms distinguish him as a politician who had the well-being of his nation at heart, although he also faced criticism and controversies.
Park Geun-hye:
Park Geun-hye was born on February 2, 1952, in Samdeok-dong, Daegu, South Korea.  She is the daughter of former South Korean President Park Chung-hee and Yuk Young-soo. 

Park Geun-hye grew up in a political family and spent her youth at the Blue House, the South Korean presidential palace.  Her father ruled the country from 1961 until his assassination in 1979.  Through her father, she was heavily influenced by political and public life and developed an early interest in politics. 

In 1974, Park Geun-hye served as First Lady after her mother was killed in an assassination during one of her father's speeches.  She supported her father in state affairs and attended official events.  This experience gave her deep insights into the complexities of South Korea's political landscape. 

In 1998, Park Geun-hye officially entered politics and joined the conservative Saenuri Party.  She quickly became a prominent politician, winning a parliamentary seat in 1998.  Her popularity grew further when she was elected as the first chairwoman of the Saenuri Party in 2004. 

In 2013, Park Geun-hye won the presidential elections, becoming the first female president of South Korea.  Her term began with high expectations, and she campaigned on promises to revitalize the economy and improve relations with North Korea. 

However, Park Geun-hye's presidency in 2016 was overshadowed by a major corruption scandal.  It was revealed that a close friend named Choi Soon-sil had significant influence over the president's political decisions and accepted bribes from companies. 

In December 2016, Park Geun-hye was impeached by the parliament and later convicted by a court in the country on charges of abuse of power, bribery, and coercion.  She was sentenced to 24 years in prison and a hefty fine. 

Park Geun-hye's presidency and conviction mark a dark chapter in South Korea's history.  Her cases of corruption and abuse of power have shaken public trust in the government and led to political reforms. 

Today, Park Geun-hye continues to live in prison, while the South Korean people continue to deal with the impact of her presidency and rebuild trust in the country's politics.
Fuad Masum:
Fuad Masum was born on January 1, 1938, in the city of Koya in present-day Iraq.  He comes from a Kurdish family and grew up in a rural environment.  Masum attended the local primary school and showed early interest in politics and law. 

After completing primary school, Masum continued his education at Baghdad University, where he studied law.  During his studies, he joined a student organization advocating for Kurdish rights and democracy promotion in Iraq.  His political involvement brought him some challenges, but he remained undeterred. 

After graduating, Masum initially worked as a lawyer and ran a law firm in his hometown of Koya.  In the 1970s, he joined the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK), a political party advocating for Kurdish autonomy in Iraq. 

During Saddam's regime, Masum was forced into exile due to his political activism.  He lived in Iran for several years and continued to work actively for the PUK.  After the fall of Saddam's regime, Masum returned to Iraq in 2003 and became a member of the governing council supporting the country's transition to democracy. 

In 2014, Masum was elected President of Iraq.  This election was historic as Masum became the first Kurdish President of the country.  During his term, he worked towards strengthening democracy, protecting human rights, and promoting national reconciliation.  He was a symbol of unity and cohesion in ethnically and religiously divided Iraq. 

Masum's presidency was marked by political instability and the threat posed by the Islamic State (IS).  Despite these challenges, he remained a dedicated and resolute leader advocating for peace and security in Iraq. 

Upon the end of his term in 2018, Masum withdrew from active politics.  He now pursues his interests in the academic world and writes on political issues.  However, his contribution to the history of Iraq and his efforts towards reconciliation and stability will remain unforgettable for many.  Fuad Masum has left a lasting impression as one of the most influential politicians in Iraq.
Ashraf Ghani:
Ashraf Ghani was born on May 19, 1949 in Kabul, Afghanistan.  He grew up in an educated and politically active family that placed great value on education.  His father, Shahbaz Ghani, was a diplomat and his mother, Ikramuddin, was a respected figure in the field of education. 

Ghani received an excellent education and completed his bachelor's degree in Economics in Kabul.  He then received a scholarship for a master's degree in Anthropology at Columbia University in the United States.  He also obtained his Ph. D.  in Anthropology there.  During his studies, he focused intensively on development issues and became an expert in this field. 

After his return to Afghanistan in 1977, Ghani was active both academically and politically.  He taught at Kabul University and worked as a consultant for various government agencies.  During the Soviet occupation, he was involved in the resistance movement against the occupation, which led to his arrest and escape to America. 

In the USA, Ghani taught at several universities, including the University of California, Berkeley, and worked as a consultant for international organizations.  During this time, he developed his theory of "good governance" and his approach to poverty reduction. 

Following the fall of the Taliban regime in 2001, Ghani returned to Afghanistan to support his country in its transformation and reconstruction.  He was appointed as Finance Minister and played a key role in stabilizing the Afghan economy and overcoming the country's heavy debt burden. 

Ghani founded the political movement "Kabul Process" in 2009 and became known as a reformer and visionary.  He advocated for strengthening democracy, eliminating corruption, and promoting human rights.  In 2014, he was elected President of Afghanistan and assumed office the same year. 

During his presidency, Ghani strongly advocated for the peace process in Afghanistan and sought to engage the Taliban in political negotiations.  He also worked to improve the security situation in the country and fought against the threat posed by terrorist groups. 

Ashraf Ghani is regarded as a knowledgeable economist who advocates for the economic development of his country.  He has driven extensive reforms in the areas of education, health, and infrastructure.  His political vision is to make Afghanistan a stable and prosperous country based on the core values of democracy and justice. 

Despite some political challenges and controversies, Ashraf Ghani remains a significant political figure in Afghanistan and continues to strive for improving the living conditions of the Afghan population.  His passion for progress and his extensive experience in governance and development have made him a key figure in Afghan politics.
Salman of Saudi Arabia:
Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud was born on December 31, 1935 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.  He is currently the King of Saudi Arabia and the head of the royal family Al Saud. 

Salman is the son of King Abdulaziz, the founder of modern Saudi Arabia, and Princess Hassa bint Ahmed Al Sudairi.  He grew up in a large family and had many brothers and sisters. 

From a young age, Salman was politically active and supported his father in governance.  He was an important part of the royal family and participated in international meetings and diplomatic missions. 

After the death of his father in 1953, Salman took on various political roles and played an active role in the country's development.  He was the Governor of Riyadh and later the Minister of Defense. 

In 2015, Salman was crowned the King of Saudi Arabia after his half-brother Abdullah bin Abdulaziz Al Saud passed away.  As King, he has worked to further modernize the country and diversify its economy.  Under his leadership, reforms in the education sector, women's rights, and economic development were implemented. 

Salman is also known for his philanthropic work.  He has established numerous charitable organizations and supports projects in the fields of education, healthcare, and poverty alleviation. 

Although Salman has faced criticism in the past, especially regarding human rights issues and interference in other countries, he has maintained close relationships with other heads of state and government around the world.  He has played an important role in promoting Saudi Arabia's relations with other countries. 

Salman is married and has several children, including his sons Muhammad bin Salman and Abdulaziz bin Salman.  Muhammad bin Salman is currently the Crown Prince and is considered a potential successor to King Salman. 

Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud has had a long political career and continues to be an influential figure as the King of Saudi Arabia.  His leadership has shaped the country and given it a leading position in the region and on the international stage.
Islam Karimov:
Islam Karimov was born on January 30, 1938 in the former Soviet republic of Uzbekistan.  He grew up in a simple family and graduated from the Tashkent Institute of Irrigation and Agricultural Mechanization.  After completing his studies, he initially worked in the agricultural sector and quickly rose to higher positions. 

In 1989, Karimov was appointed Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic.  He used this position to advance his political career and expand his control over politics in Uzbekistan. 

With the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, Karimov declared Uzbekistan's independence and was elected as the country's first president.  In the following years, he consolidated his power and severely restricted political opposition and free media. 

Karimov implemented a policy of economic reforms to modernize the country and improve the standard of living for the population.  However, the prosperity mainly benefited the elite, while the majority of the Uzbek population continued to live in poverty. 

Karimov's authoritarian regime became known for human rights abuses, arbitrary arrests, torture, and restrictions on freedom of speech and press.  Critics of the regime were persecuted and opposition politicians were exiled from the country. 

Islam Karimov ruled Uzbekistan with an iron fist for 27 years until his death in September 2016.  His authoritarian leadership left a fragile legacy marked by political repression and economic inequalities. 

Despite the controversies surrounding his rule, Karimov is seen by some as a visionary who led the country in an unstable region and helped Uzbekistan achieve some economic development.  Others, however, view him as an oppressor who disregarded the freedom and human rights of the Uzbek population.
Najib Razak:
Najib Razak was born on July 23, 1953 in Kuala Lipis, Pahang, Malaysia.  He comes from a prominent political family, as both his father Abdul Razak Hussein and his uncle Hussein Onn were former Prime Ministers of Malaysia. 

Razak received his education abroad and obtained a degree in Economics from the University of Nottingham in the United Kingdom.  Upon returning to Malaysia, he joined the United Malays National Organization (UMNO) in 1976, a political party that has dominated the government since Malaysia's independence in 1957. 

Razak worked hard to establish himself within the party, taking on various ministerial positions in the government, including Minister of Youth and Sports and Minister of Defense.  In 2004, he was appointed Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance. 

In 2009, Razak succeeded Abdullah Badawi as the Prime Minister of Malaysia.  During his tenure, he focused on promoting economic growth and modernizing the country's infrastructure.  He launched the "1Malaysia" program aimed at fostering ethnic and religious harmony in a society with many different cultures. 

Despite some positive achievements during his time in office, Razak faced several corruption and mismanagement scandals.  The most notorious of these is the 1MDB scandal, involving billions of dollars being misappropriated from a government fund.  Razak was accused of being involved in the scandal and in July 2018, he was charged with corruption, money laundering, and abuse of power. 

In the general elections of May 2018, Razak's UMNO party lost government power for the first time since Malaysia's independence.  His successor, Mahathir Mohamad, accused Razak and his government of corruption and improper handling of government affairs. 

Najib Razak is currently facing trial and has to answer to the charges of corruption.  His political career is severely damaged, and his legacy as the Prime Minister of Malaysia is overshadowed by the corruption allegations.  Nonetheless, he will be remembered as an influential figure in the history of Malaysia and one of the longest-serving Prime Ministers of the country.
Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi:
Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi was born on September 1, 1945 in the city of Abyan in southern Yemen.  He studied engineering at the University of Sanaa and obtained a bachelor's degree in 1968. 

In the 1970s and 1980s, Hadi worked for the Ministry of Planning and Development in Yemen and held various positions in this field.  He became known for his expertise in economic issues and his commitment to the development of his country. 

In 1994, Hadi assumed the position of Deputy Minister of Planning and Development.  During this time, he worked closely with then-President Ali Abdullah Saleh and supported various development projects in Yemen. 

In 1998, Saleh appointed Hadi as the Vice President of Yemen.  This position strengthened Hadi's political influence, and he played a significant role in formulating and implementing reforms in various areas of the country. 

After the outbreak of the Arab Spring in 2011 and the related protests in Yemen, President Saleh was ousted by a transitional government supported by the international community.  Hadi assumed the presidency and initiated the transitional period. 

During his presidency, Hadi advocated for democratization in Yemen and attempted to restore the country's security and stability.  He engaged in negotiations with various political groups and worked towards forming an inclusive government that takes into account the interests of all Yemeni population groups. 

However, Hadi soon faced significant political and security challenges.  Yemen plunged into a bloody civil war as Houthi rebels from the north of the country sought to overthrow the government.  In 2015, Hadi fled the capital Sanaa and continued his government in exile in the southern city of Aden. 

Since then, Hadi has continued to try to resolve the conflict in Yemen and achieve a political agreement.  He has sought international support and negotiated with various regional actors.  Nevertheless, the civil war remains ongoing to this day, and Yemen continues to be marked by political instability, a humanitarian crisis, and widespread poverty. 

Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi is known for his calmness and composure, his ability to mediate between various political actors, and his tireless dedication to peace and stability in his country.  He has shown himself to be a committed statesman in challenging times, striving to guide Yemen towards recovery and prosperity.
Sushil Koirala:
Sushil Koirala was born on August 12, 1939 in Biratnagar, Nepal.  He comes from a politically active family, as both his father, Matrika Prasad Koirala, and his uncle, Bishweshwar Prasad Koirala, were political leaders. 

Koirala received a good education and successfully completed his schooling.  With his passion for politics, he followed in his family's footsteps and became involved early on in the Nepali Congress Party, one of Nepal's major political parties. 

During his political career, Koirala played a crucial role in promoting democracy and democratization in Nepal.  He actively participated in political movements and protests against the authoritarian rule of the king. 

In 1991, democracy was restored in Nepal with the abandonment of one-party rule.  Koirala was elected as a member of the Constituent Assembly and played a key role in drafting Nepal's new constitution. 

In 2014, Sushil Koirala was elected as the Prime Minister of Nepal.  During his tenure, he was instrumental in restoring political stability and advancing the country's socio-economic development.  He advocated for rebuilding after the devastating earthquake of 2015 and also worked towards promoting education and healthcare in Nepal. 

Unfortunately, Koirala’s tenure was overshadowed by health issues.  He suffered from lung cancer and passed away on February 9, 2016, at the age of 76. 

Sushil Koirala is appreciated for his contribution to the democratization of Nepal and the promotion of political stability in the region.  As one of the country's most prominent politicians, he left a legacy that continues to live on even after his death.
Vladimir Putin:
Vladimir Putin was born on October 7, 1952 in Leningrad (today St.  Petersburg) in the former Soviet Union.  He grew up in a simple working-class family and developed an early interest in martial arts, particularly judo.  Putin started training at a young age and later achieved a black belt in judo. 

After completing his schooling, Putin studied law at Leningrad State University, graduating in 1975.  He then began his career at the Soviet secret service KGB.  Putin held various positions within the intelligence service and was appointed deputy mayor of Leningrad in 1991. 

Following the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 and the formation of the Russian Federation, Putin was appointed to the emerging Russian government service.  In 1999, he was appointed Prime Minister and took over the country's leadership during a period of political turmoil and economic difficulties. 

Putin was inaugurated as President of the Russian Federation in 2000.  During his presidency, he focused on consolidating power and rebuilding the Russian economy.  Putin also implemented a series of political reforms aimed at strengthening the state's authority and protecting Russian sovereignty. 

Under Putin, Russia experienced a period of economic growth, accompanied by a strengthened role on the international stage.  However, Putin has also faced criticism for restricting freedom of speech and suppressing political opposition. 

After two terms as President, Putin became Prime Minister in 2008 and handed over the presidency to his ally Dmitry Medvedev.  In 2012, Putin was re-elected as President and began his third term. 

During Putin's presidency, Russia has increased in influence and political significance.  Putin is known for his strong leadership style and nationalist policies.  In recent years, he has been involved in international conflicts such as the annexation of Crimea and the Syrian war. 

Despite international criticism and controversial views on his political leadership, Putin remains a influential figure in global politics and continues to influence Russia's political climate.
Joachim Gauck:
Joachim Gauck was born on January 24, 1940 in Rostock, Germany.  He grew up in a deeply religious family, his father was a pastor, and the Christian value system had a strong influence on his life from the beginning. 

In 1957, Gauck completed his high school education and then began studying theology at the University of Rostock.  After successfully completing his studies, he first worked as a pastor in Mecklenburg.  From 1984 to 1990, he was a pastor at St.  Johannis Church in Rostock. 

The reunification of Germany marked a new era for Gauck.  In 1990, he was appointed as the head of the Stasi Records Agency, where he played a crucial role in processing the secret files of the Stasi.  As a longtime member of the civil rights movement in East Germany, Gauck was a fervent advocate for freedom and the rule of law. 

Through his work at the Stasi Records Agency, Gauck became a symbol for addressing the past and building a democratic society in Germany.  His dedication and credibility made him one of the most prominent figures in Germany. 

In 2012, Gauck was elected as the President of Germany by the Federal Assembly.  During his tenure, he advocated for social justice, the protection of human rights, and the promotion of democracy and freedom.  Gauck consistently emphasized the importance of tolerance, respect, and cohesion in a pluralistic society. 

After his term ended in 2017, Gauck largely withdrew from the political limelight but remained active as an author and speaker.  Joachim Gauck is admired for his passionate commitment to democracy and human rights, and through his actions and experiences, he has inspired many people worldwide.
David Cameron:
David Cameron was born on October 9, 1966, in London.  He grew up in an affluent family, his father was a wealthy businessman and his mother was a legal secretary.  Cameron attended the prestigious Eton College and later studied at the University of Oxford, where he studied Politics, Philosophy, and Economics. 

From an early age, Cameron showed an interest in politics and joined the Conservative Party in 1988.  His political career started in the office of Chancellor Norman Lamont, where he worked as a Special Adviser.  During this time, he gained valuable insights into government policy and developed his skills as a political strategist. 

In 2001, Cameron was first elected as the Member of Parliament for Witney in the British House of Commons.  He quickly made a name for himself as an eloquent speaker and skilled tactician.  In 2005, he was appointed to the Shadow Cabinet of the Conservative Party for the first time and took on the role of Shadow Minister for Education. 

Cameron worked hard to modernize the image of the Conservative Party and appeal to a broader range of voters.  He emphasized issues such as education, poverty alleviation, and advocated for a more inclusive and environmentally conscious policy.  Under his leadership, the Conservative Party won a majority in the 2010 general election, and Cameron was appointed as the British Prime Minister. 

During his tenure as Prime Minister, Cameron championed a number of reforms, including the introduction of same-sex marriage and a stronger integration of the UK into the European Union.  He also implemented several austerity measures to reduce the budget deficit and boost the economy. 

One of the biggest challenges of his time in office was the Brexit referendum in 2016.  Despite his efforts to keep Britain in the European Union, the majority of the population voted to leave.  Shocked by this result, Cameron resigned from the position of Prime Minister. 

After stepping down from active politics, Cameron focused on writing and charity work.  He published his memoirs and advocated for projects related to education and global development.  Despite his ups and downs, Cameron is still considered one of the most influential politicians in recent British history.
Fran\u00e7ois Hollande:
François Gérard Georges Nicolas Hollande was born on August 12, 1954 in Rouen, France.  He grew up in a politically active family; his father was the mayor of Rouen and his mother was a social worker. 

Hollande studied political science at the prestigious École nationale d'administration (ENA) and successfully completed his studies in 1980.  He then entered public service and worked, among other places, in the Ministry of Finance. 

Hollande began his political career in the 1980s in the Socialist Party.  He was appointed as an advisor to then President François Mitterrand and held various positions within the party.  In 1997, he was elected as the chairman of the Socialist Party, a position he held until 2008. 

In 2012, Hollande ran in the presidential elections and eventually won against the incumbent president Nicolas Sarkozy.  He became the 24th President of the French Republic and the first socialist president since 1995. 

As president, Hollande implemented a series of political reforms, including a tax reform, the introduction of the minimum wage, and the legalization of same-sex marriage.  However, he also faced numerous challenges, such as rising unemployment and a growing wealth gap. 

In 2017, Hollande chose not to seek re-election and left office with low approval ratings in opinion polls.  Since then, he has been working as a speaker and author, continuing to advocate for socialist ideals. 

François Hollande is praised for his modest and approachable style and is considered one of the most respected French politicians of recent history.  Although he experienced both successes and failures during his tenure, he will be remembered for his efforts to promote social justice and economic balance.
Sergio Mattarella:
Sergio Mattarella was born on July 23, 1941 in Palermo, Sicily.  He came from a politically active family: his father Bernardo Mattarella was a respected politician and lawyer who strongly advocated for the independence of Sicily. 

After completing his law studies at the University of Palermo, Mattarella began a successful career as a lawyer and lecturer in constitutional law.  He showed early interest in political issues and became active in the Christian Democratic Party (DC) of Sicily in the 1970s. 

Mattarella was elected as a member of the Italian Parliament in 1983 and held various important positions during his political career.  From 1989 to 1990, he served as Minister of Public Education in Giulio Andreotti's government, and from 1998, he held the position of Deputy Prime Minister under Romano Prodi. 

Mattarella was known for his high level of integrity and adherence to principles.  He was willing to jeopardize political relationships in favor of his beliefs.  He demonstrated this particularly during the anti-mafia campaign of the 1990s, when he served as Minister for Regional Affairs and Minister of Defense.  He actively fought against organized crime and bravely battled its influence on politics. 

In January 2015, Sergio Mattarella was elected as the eleventh President of the Italian Republic.  As President, he pursued a policy of unity and social cohesion.  He sought to overcome political tensions in the country and promoted dialogue between different political parties. 

Mattarella is also a staunch European and advocated for stronger integration and cooperation within the European Union.  He pushed for reforms in the judicial system and called for an effective fight against corruption as well as a strengthening of democracy and the rule of law. 

Sergio Mattarella is married and has three children.  He is considered a modest and reserved politician who prefers to stay in the background.  Nevertheless, he has a significant influence on Italy's political landscape and tirelessly advocates for the country's interests and its citizens.  His principles, integrity, and commitment have made him a respected figure who is recognized well beyond Italy's borders.
Mariano Rajoy:
Mariano Rajoy Brey was born on March 27, 1955 in Santiago de Compostela, Spain.  He grew up in a middle-class family and was interested in politics from an early age.  After completing his education, he studied Law and Public Administration at the Universidad de Santiago de Compostela. 

Rajoy's political career began in the 1980s when he joined the Partido Popular (PP).  During that time, he worked closely with the then Spanish Prime Minister, José María Aznar, and played an important role in modernizing the party.  In 1996, Rajoy was appointed Minister of Education and Culture, and in 2000, he became the Deputy Prime Minister. 

In 2004, Rajoy was elected as the leader of the PP.  As a prominent figure in Spanish conservatives, he was a staunch critic of the socialist government led by Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero.  Rajoy promised to strengthen the Spanish economy and create jobs.  In 2011, he led the PP to an absolute majority in the parliamentary elections and was appointed as the Spanish Prime Minister. 

As Prime Minister, Rajoy focused on resolving the economic crisis that had hit Spain hard.  During his tenure, he introduced comprehensive austerity measures and advocated for structural reforms to improve the competitiveness of the Spanish economy.  Although his budget cuts led to social unrest, Rajoy managed to restore confidence in the international markets and set the economy back on a growth path. 

Rajoy faced several political challenges, including the Catalan independence movement.  In 2017, the Catalan regional government declared independence from Spain, leading to a constitutional crisis.  Rajoy reacted decisively by imposing direct control over Catalonia.  Under his leadership, the leaders of the independence movement were brought to trial and some were sentenced to prison. 

In 2018, Rajoy lost the confidence of the parliament and was ousted as Prime Minister.  He was succeeded by Pedro Sánchez.  Rajoy retired from politics and in 2019 he announced his resignation as the leader of the PP. 

Mariano Rajoy is often praised for his ability to demonstrate leadership in difficult times and to implement important reforms.  During his tenure, he managed to stabilize the Spanish economy and lead the country out of the crisis.  Rajoy is considered one of the most influential political figures in recent Spanish history.
Petro Poroshenko:
Petro Poroshenko was born on September 26, 1965 in Bolhrad, a city in Ukraine.  His family had played a significant role in Ukrainian politics and economy for several generations. 

Poroshenko studied at Taras Shevchenko National University in Kyiv and obtained a degree in international trade law.  He started his entrepreneurial activities during his studies and founded his first company at the age of 21.  This marked the beginning of a successful career as an entrepreneur and industrialist. 

In 1998, Poroshenko was elected Chairman of the Council of the Ukrainian Industrial and Entrepreneurial Union.  In this position, he advocated for the strengthening of the Ukrainian economy and the promotion of entrepreneurship. 

Over the years, Poroshenko built an empire of companies engaged in various sectors such as confectionery, automotive, and television.  These successes made him one of the wealthiest men in Ukraine. 

Poroshenko's political career began in 2001 when he was elected as a member of the Ukrainian Parliament.  He joined President Viktor Yanukovych's Party of Regions and was appointed as Ukraine's Foreign Minister in 2009.  In this role, he advocated for Ukraine's closer ties with the European Union and played a key role in the negotiations on the Association Agreement. 

However, the peak of Poroshenko's political career came during the Maidan protests in 2014.  After President Yanukovych was overthrown, Poroshenko was elected Chairman of the Ukrainian Parliament.  Just a few months later, in May 2014, he won the presidential elections and was sworn in as the President of Ukraine. 

As President, Poroshenko continued his efforts to reform Ukraine economically and strengthen its relations with the European Union.  He also introduced a series of measures against corruption and took a strong stance against Russian aggression in Ukraine, particularly in the conflict in eastern Ukraine. 

Poroshenko ran for re-election in the 2019 presidential elections but was not able to defeat his rival, Volodymyr Zelensky.  Nonetheless, he remains a significant politician and entrepreneur in Ukraine, continuing to advocate for the values of democracy, freedom, and sovereignty of his country.
Andrzej Duda:
Andrzej Duda was born on May 16, 1972 in Krakow, Poland.  He grew up in a politically engaged family, his father Jan Tadeusz Duda was a member of the oppositional Solidarity movement. 

Duda studied law at the Jagiellonian University in Krakow and graduated with distinction in 1997.  In the following years, he worked as an assistant at the Faculty of Law and Administration and presented his doctoral thesis on the topic "The fundamental right to property according to the Polish Constitution". 

His political career began in 2001 when he became a member of the Law and Justice (PiS) party.  In 2005, he was appointed as an advisor to the Polish President Lech Kaczyński and later as Deputy Minister of Justice. 

In 2014, Duda ran as the PiS candidate in the presidential elections and surprisingly defeated the incumbent Bronisław Komorowski.  On August 6, 2015, he was sworn in as the new President of Poland. 

As President, Duda has pursued a conservative agenda focused on protecting traditional values and promoting national interests.  He has repeatedly expressed his opposition to the European Union and its proposals on migration policy. 

Duda has often been criticized for his decisions and actions, especially for his support of the controversial judicial reform program that questions the independence of the Polish judiciary.  Furthermore, he has also been criticized for his restrictions on press freedom and his nationalist rhetoric. 

Nevertheless, Andrzej Duda remains popular among many Poles, especially in rural areas, where he is seen as a defender of the interests of the "ordinary people".  In the 2020 presidential elections, he ran again as the PiS candidate and narrowly won a runoff against opposition candidate Rafał Trzaskowski. 

Andrzej Duda is married to Agata Kornhauser-Duda and has a daughter with her.  In his free time, he is interested in sports, especially table tennis and football.
Klaus Iohannis:
Klaus Iohannis was born on June 13, 1959 in the city of Sibiu, Romania.  He comes from a German minority in Romania and grew up in a middle-class household.  His parents were Transylvanian Saxons who ran a plumbing fixture factory in Sibiu. 

Iohannis attended the German school in Sibiu, where he deepened his knowledge of German and developed a strong connection to German culture and language.  After graduating from school, he studied Physics at Babes-Bolyai University in Cluj-Napoca. 

After completing his studies, Iohannis worked as a physics teacher and held various positions in school administration.  His reputation as an efficient and capable administrator grew, and he was eventually elected Mayor of Sibiu in 2000. 

During his term as mayor, Iohannis implemented important reforms to modernize Sibiu and make it internationally known.  Under his leadership, the city developed into a significant cultural center and tourist destination.  These successes earned him recognition and made him a leading voice in Romanian politics. 

Iohannis joined the National Liberal Party (PNL) and was nominated by them as a candidate for the presidency.  In 2014, he was eventually elected President of Romania.  Iohannis is the first Romanian President of German descent and has established himself as a non-partisan and pro-European politician. 

As President, Iohannis has worked closely with the government to drive important reforms in the education and judicial systems and combat corruption in Romania.  His commitment to the rule of law principles and his contribution to strengthening relations with other EU countries have earned him international recognition. 

Klaus Iohannis is known for his calm and factual manner in convincing his political opponents and finding political compromises.  He is admired for his integrity and leadership qualities and continues to play a significant role in Romanian politics.
Mark Rutte:
Mark Rutte was born on February 14, 1967, in The Hague, Netherlands.  He grew up in a politically active family, his father was a senior civil servant and his mother was a teacher.  This early influence shaped Rutte's later political involvement. 

After graduating from Johan de Witt Gymnasium, Rutte studied History at Leiden University.  During his studies, he joined the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD), a liberal and conservative party in the Netherlands. 

In 1992, Rutte completed his studies and started his professional career in the corporate sector.  He initially worked for Unilever and later for the Human Resources department of the company Wehkamp.  Despite his success in the private sector, Rutte was drawn to politics. 

In 2002, Rutte was elected as a Member of the Second Chamber of Parliament.  There, he quickly made a name for himself, particularly for his strong knowledge in economic and financial matters.  This expertise led to his appointment as State Secretary for Social Affairs and Employment in 2004.  In this position, he played a key role in implementing labor law reforms. 

In 2006, Rutte was elected as the leader of the VVD, becoming the political leader of his party.  In the 2010 elections, the VVD won the most seats in parliament and Rutte was appointed as the Prime Minister of the Netherlands.  In this role, he led a conservative coalition government focusing on strengthening the economy and reducing public debt. 

Rutte steered the country through challenging times, including the Euro crisis and the refugee crisis.  He gained recognition for his pragmatic and decisive policies and was re-elected as Prime Minister in 2012.  In the 2017 elections, Rutte maintained his position and started his third term as the Dutch Prime Minister. 

As Prime Minister, Rutte pursued a liberal agenda with a focus on economic growth, fiscal consolidation, and a restrictive immigration policy.  He was a strong supporter of the European Union and advocated for closer cooperation between member states. 

Rutte is seen as a pragmatic and goal-oriented politician who has managed to earn the trust of the Dutch population.  His popularity is reflected in his continuous re-elections.
Charles Michel:
Charles Michel was born on December 21, 1975, in Namur, Belgium.  He comes from a politically engaged family, as his father Louis Michel was also a well-known politician who held various ministerial positions in Belgium. 

Michel completed his law studies at the University of Namur and the Free University of Brussels.  During his studies, he became a member of the youth organization of the Mouvement Réformateur (MR), a liberal Belgian party. 

His political career began at a young age when he worked as a staff member for various politicians and ministries in Belgium starting in 1994.  In 1999, he became the youngest member of the Belgian Parliament and served on the Committee on Internal Affairs.  In 2000, he was appointed as the chairman of the MR Youth Organization and Vice President of the MR. 

In 2007, Michel was elected as a member of the Belgian Parliament and shortly after assumed the position of Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Budget in Yves Leterme's cabinet.  In 2011, he was elected as the chairman of the MR and initiated a modernization of the party. 

When Elio Di Rupo's government collapsed in 2014, Michel was tasked with forming a new government.  He became the youngest Prime Minister in Belgium's history and led a coalition government composed of liberal, conservative, and Flemish separatist parties.  During his tenure, he focused on economic reforms, measures to strengthen security, and the expansion of infrastructure. 

In 2019, Michel left Belgian politics to pursue an international career.  He was appointed as the President of the European Council and assumed his office on December 1, 2019.  In this role, he coordinates the policies of EU member states and represents the EU externally.  He has been particularly active in advocating for issues such as climate change, digitalization, and the reform of the EU. 

Charles Michel is known for his eloquent and composed demeanor.  With his charisma and political skills, he has gained recognition in Belgium and internationally.  He is seen as a leading political figure who advocates for his vision of a united and strong Europe.
Milo\u0161 Zeman:
Miloš Zeman was born on September 28, 1944 in the Czech city of Kolín.  He grew up in a working-class family and attended high school in Kolín.  After graduating, he studied at the University of Economics in Prague and completed his studies in 1968 with a master's degree. 

During his studies, Zeman was politically active and joined the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia in 1968.  He became a member of the party's Central Committee and played an active role during the Prague Spring.  After the suppression of the reform movement, he was expelled from the party but was able to rejoin in 1975. 

In the 1980s, Zeman worked as the director of an economic magazine and emerged as a critical voice against the communist government.  With the fall of the Iron Curtain in 1989, he became more politically active and co-founded the Czech Social Democratic Party (ČSSD). 

In 1993, Zeman was elected to the Czech Parliament and served as the Prime Minister of the Czech Republic from 1998 to 2002.  During his tenure, he implemented economic reforms and advocated for Czech Republic's accession to the European Union. 

After his time as Prime Minister, Zeman withdrew from politics and engaged in various activities, including writing books and working as a consultant.  However, in 2013, he re-entered politics and ran in the presidential elections in the Czech Republic. 

Miloš Zeman won the elections and was sworn in as President on March 8, 2013.  During his presidency, he advocated for a pro-Russian foreign policy and was a critic of the European Union.  He became known for his controversial statements and often made headlines. 

In January 2018, Zeman was re-elected for a second term and began his second term in March of the same year. 

Miloš Zeman is considered one of the most influential political figures in the Czech Republic and has significantly shaped the country's political landscape since the 1990s.
Prokopis Pavlopoulos:
Prokopis Pavlopoulos was born on July 10, 1950 in Kalamata, Greece.  He grew up in a politically engaged family and developed an early interest in politics. 

After completing his high school education, Pavlopoulos studied law at the University of Athens.  During his studies, he actively participated in the student movement against the military dictatorship at the time.  His political activism led to conflicts with the authorities, resulting in his temporary arrest. 

After graduation, Pavlopoulos worked as a research assistant at the University of Athens and obtained a doctorate in criminal law.  He later specialized in constitutional law and became a renowned expert in the field. 

In addition to his academic career, Pavlopoulos entered politics.  He joined the center-right New Democracy party and was elected to parliament in 1996.  During his time in parliament, he held various ministerial positions, including Minister of Culture, Minister of the Interior, and Minister of Justice. 

In 2015, Pavlopoulos was elected President of Greece.  In this role, he represents the state externally and mainly performs ceremonial duties.  Despite his mostly symbolic position, Pavlopoulos has regularly expressed his views on current political issues. 

Prokopis Pavlopoulos is considered an experienced politician with extensive expertise.  He advocates for the preservation and strengthening of democratic principles in Greece and has promoted various political and social reforms during his presidency. 

Outside of politics, Pavlopoulos is an avid reader who enjoys literature and philosophy.  He is married and has two children. 

With his calm and respectful demeanor, Pavlopoulos has earned recognition both within Greece and internationally.  His political and academic contributions, along with his extensive experience, make him a significant figure in Greek politics.
Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa:
Marcelo Nuno Duarte Rebelo de Sousa was born on December 12, 1948, in Lisbon, Portugal.  He is a Portuguese politician, lawyer, and the current President of Portugal. 

Rebelo de Sousa comes from a politically active family.  His father, Baltasar Rebelo de Sousa, was a well-known doctor and politician, who stood out as a leading member of the Social Democratic Party of Portugal (PSD).  His mother, Maria das Neves Fernandes Duarte Rebelo de Sousa, was a respected teacher. 

After completing school, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa started studying Law at the Faculty of Law of the University of Lisbon.  Already during his studies, he became politically involved and joined the PSD.  In 1971, he graduated and began his academic career as an assistant professor of Constitutional Law. 

In the 1980s, Rebelo de Sousa gained recognition through his appearances as a commentator and political analyst on television.  He was known for his strong opinions and ability to explain complex political situations in a comprehensible manner. 

In 1996, he was elected Vice President of the PSD and played a crucial role in the party in the following years.  In 1999, he took a political step and unsuccessfully ran for the position of Mayor of Lisbon.  Despite his defeat, he retained his influence within the party. 

In the following years, he taught at various universities and continued to appear frequently as a political analyst in the media.  In 2016, Rebelo de Sousa finally decided to run for the office of the President of Portugal.  With great success, he won the election and took office on March 9, 2016. 

As the President of Portugal, Rebelo de Sousa has a mostly representative role.  However, he actively advocated for improving Portugal's relationships with other countries and for economic reforms.  Especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, he appeared as a reassuring figure and worked towards uniting the country in challenging times. 

Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa is known for his open and friendly personality.  He enjoys high popularity in Portugal and is valued for his ability to connect with people and listen to them.  His political success and popularity make him a significant figure in Portuguese politics.
Stefan L\u00f6fven:
Stefan Löfven was born on July 21, 1957 in Stockholm, Sweden.  He grew up in the small town of Ådalen and spent his childhood and teenage years there. 

Löfven's political engagement began early.  At the age of 13, he joined the Swedish Social Democratic Worker Party (SAP), which would significantly shape his life and career.  Over the following years, he worked in various jobs alongside his involvement in the party, including as a welder, warehouse worker, and union representative.  These experiences were crucial for his later political orientation and his focus on social justice and labor rights. 

Löfven started his political career in the 1990s when he was appointed as the chairman of the Metal Workers' Union.  This role allowed him to advocate for the interests of workers and employees, and to push for better working conditions and wages. 

In 2012, Löfven was elected as the leader of the Social Democratic Worker Party.  He succeeded Håkan Juholt and took over the leadership of a party that was struggling in polls at the time.  However, Löfven managed to revitalize the party and strengthen its positions. 

Löfven's political career reached its peak in 2014 when he was elected as the Prime Minister of Sweden.  He led a coalition government consisting of the Social Democratic Worker Party and the Greens.  In his role as Prime Minister, he advocated for social justice, education, and environmental protection, and strived for an open and inclusive society. 

During his time as Prime Minister, Löfven also focused on addressing the refugee crisis in Europe and advocated for a humanitarian immigration policy.  His positions in this area, however, were controversial and faced criticism. 

In June 2018, Löfven resigned as Prime Minister after his government party did not win a majority in the parliamentary elections.  Nevertheless, he remained an influential member of the Social Democratic Worker Party and was reappointed as Prime Minister in January 2019 after forming a coalition government with the Green Party Miljöpartiet de Gröna. 

Throughout his political career, Stefan Löfven has achieved many successes but also faced criticism.  He has championed social justice and workers' rights, as well as tackled challenges such as refugee integration and climate change. 

Despite all the political storms, Löfven has remained a passionate advocate for his beliefs and has continuously stood up for those in society who need the most help.  His life story is an example of a remarkable political career based on commitment, hard work, and the pursuit of social justice.
J\u00e1nos \u00c1der:
János Áder was born on May 9, 1959 in Csorna, Hungary.  Áder grew up in a simple family and showed early interest in politics and environmental protection.  He studied law at Eötvös Loránd University in Budapest and graduated in 1983. 

After his studies, Áder worked as a lawyer and simultaneously engaged in various environmental organizations.  He became a well-known activist in Hungary, advocating for the preservation of natural resources and the fight against climate change. 

Áder joined the Hungarian Democratic Forum Party (MDF) and started his political career.  In 1990, he was first elected to the Hungarian Parliament and worked as a member of parliament.  Áder was a rising political talent and quickly became a prominent member of the MDF. 

In 1998, Áder was elected as the deputy chairman of the MDF.  This position helped him advance his political career and demonstrate his skills as a leader. 

When the MDF failed in the 2000 parliamentary elections, Áder left the party and, along with other politicians, founded the Fidesz-Hungarian Civic Alliance.  Under the leadership of Viktor Orbán, the Fidesz party won the majority in the 2010 elections, and Áder was elected to parliament. 

In 2012, Áder was eventually elected as the President of Hungary.  As President, he focused mainly on promoting environmental protection and sustainability.  He actively advocated for the protection of Hungarian rivers, forests, and the natural environment.  Áder also participated in international environmental conferences and called for stronger cooperation among countries in combating climate change. 

Áder was re-elected in 2017 for a second term and continues to be a key player in Hungarian politics.  His work and dedication to environmental protection have earned him recognition worldwide.
Alexander Lukashenko:
Alexander Lukashenko was born on August 30, 1954 in Kopys, Belarus.  He grew up in a simple working-class family and completed his schooling at the rural village school. 

After finishing school, Lukashenko studied agronomy at the Belarusian State Agricultural Academy.  In the 1980s, he worked as the director of a collective farm and eventually rose to become the chairman of a district council. 

In 1994, Lukashenko was elected President of Belarus and has been in office since then.  As President, he introduced an authoritarian government and strengthened the state's influence on the country's economy.  He also implemented various political and economic reforms to protect national interests and consolidate control over the country. 

However, Lukashenko has faced criticism for his policy of suppressing the opposition and restricting freedom of speech.  In recent years, the President has increasingly faced international isolation as his government has been accused of human rights abuses and electoral fraud. 

Despite international criticism and sanctions, Lukashenko has successfully maintained his power and has repeatedly won re-election in presidential elections.  As a result, he has achieved one of the longest presidencies in Europe. 

Alexander Lukashenko's biography is characterized by strong personal leadership and a harsh crackdown on the opposition.  While some view him as a charismatic leader, others criticize him as an authoritarian ruler who abuses his power.
